A Comparative Study of Two Wayfinding Aids With Simulated Driving Tasks—GPS and a Dual-Scale Exploration Aid

Binfeng Li State Key Laboratory of Automobile Safety and Energy, and Department of Industrial Engineering , Tsinghua University , Beijing , China , Keming Zhu State Key Laboratory of Automobile Safety and Energy, and Department of Industrial Engineering , Tsinghua University , Beijing , China , Wei Zhang State Key Laboratory of Automobile Safety and Energy, and Department of Industrial Engineering , Tsinghua University , Beijing , China Correspondencezhangwei@tsinghua.edu.cn
, Anna Wu College of Information Sciences and Technology , Pennsylvania State University , University Park , PA , USA & Xiaolong Zhang College of Information Sciences and Technology , Pennsylvania State University , University Park , PA , USA
Pages 169-177
Accepted author version posted online: 20 Jun 2012
Published online:27 Jan 2013
  • Download citation
  • https://doi.org/10.1080/10447318.2012.702634

            Articles

            A Comparative Study of Two Wayfinding Aids With Simulated Driving Tasks—GPS and a Dual-Scale Exploration Aid

            • Full Article
            • Figures & data
            • References
            • Citations
            • Metrics
            • Reprints & Permissions
            • PDF

            Abstract

            Global Positioning System (GPS) is currently the most often used wayfinding aid for driving. Yet GPS is originally designed to provide a driving guide rather than to help users gain spatial knowledge. Accordingly, GPS might be less usable in situations where spatial knowledge is required. This study experimentally compared two wayfinding aids using simulated driving tasks in a virtual environment: a simulated GPS and a dual-scale exploration aid (DSEA). The DSEA, which provides two levels of details—both detailed and contextual information—was proposed to support participants in finding and selecting routes by themselves. The results show that although DSEA was less helpful in leading participants to their destination and corresponded to more turning errors in simulated driving, it was more useful for the corresponding participants to establish spatial awareness and a cognitive map. The influence of participants' spatial ability test score on wayfinding performance was measured and discussed. The proposed DSEA design and experimental results show some indications for designing new wayfinding aids aimed at reducing wayfinding errors and constructing cognitive maps while still providing easy navigation.

            1. INTRODUCTION

            Wayfinding is a common activity in both daily life and work. In many cases, wayfinding aids are important when people need to perform wayfinding tasks in an unfamiliar environment. Among various developed wayfinding aids, Global Positioning System (GPS) is the most popular and practical one for automobile drivers (Darken, 1995; Ishikawa, Fujiwara, Imai, & Okabe, 2008; Wu, Zhang, & Zhang, 2009). According to one report, global shipments of GPS-enabled handsets are expected to reach 560 million units in 2012 (Wu, Zhang, & Zhang, 2008). In 2011, China market sold 12.13 million automobile GPSs, including about 6 million portable navigation devices (GPS) and more than 6 million GPSs integrated with DVD device (http://auto.hexun.com/2012-02-20/138424059.html [Chinese]). GPS-based guidance has become a common accessory for automobile drivers and even for pedestrians to improve their mobility.

            Yet GPS has some major drawbacks: The resolution of commonly used GPS products is not sufficient in some situations (e.g., it is sometimes difficult for GPS to distinguish between driving on a highway and driving on a nearby sideway), and accordingly, a GPS may provide incorrect guiding information (Aporta & Higgs, 2005; Fenech, Drews, & Bakdash, 2010; Wu et al., 2008); several researchers also noticed that wayfinding with GPS devices hinders the development of cognitive maps and results in poor spatial awareness and poor memory about the environment (Burnett & Lee, 2005; Forbes, 2006). These side effects limit the use of GPS in some special situations, such as military actions (e.g., antiterrorism fighting), firefighter training, and emergency rescue in unfamiliar places (Bliss, 1997; Wu et al., 2009), in which navigators need to gain as much spatial knowledge about the environment as possible and be able to explore the space so that they acquire sufficient information and confidence to accomplish their plans.

            Multiscale information display methods have been proposed to help wayfinding users construct cognitive maps by effectively connecting local objects and environmental overview information (Beard & Walker, 1990; Card, Mackinlay, & Shneiderman, 1999; Zhang, 2008). A significant reduction in screen costs, which has occurred recently, makes multiscale information display possible with a larger and wider screen size. To implement a multiscale display using a larger size screen, it is necessary to investigate the usefulness of designs with multiscale information.

            To experimentally test the usefulness of wayfinding aid designs, one can use either on-road driving tasks or simulated driving tasks. Although an on-road field study can provide the most convincing results, this study method is not only costly but also risky to the driving participants, and accordingly it is usually only used to validate the results of simulation-based studies. Compared to on-road field study method, simulated studies with driving tasks in virtual environments is less expensive and has no risk. Prior studies have proven similarities of spatial knowledge between the cases of real and virtual environments (Goerger, Darken, Boyd, & Gagnon, 1998; May, Peruch, & Savoyant, 1995; Ruddle, Payne, & Jones, 1997; Shin, 2009; Witmer, Bailey, Knerr, & Parsons, 1996) and have confirmed that spatial knowledge gained from a virtual environment can be adopted in reality (Peruch, Vercher, & Gauthier, 1995; Waller, Hunt, & Knapp, 1998). Wang, et al. (2010) also showed that simulated driving method can usually give results with either absolute or relative validity.

            In this study, we choose to compare a simulated regular GPS with a dual-scale exploration aid (DSEA; a dual-scale information display) through simulated driving tasks in a virtual environment. In this study, participants' performances, spatial knowledge acquisition, and subjective evaluation with regard to these two wayfinding aids are measured and compared. The influence of individual's spatial ability on these variables is also measured. The remainder of this article is organized as follows: Section 2 reviews the relevant literature about theories and techniques in real and virtual environments; then section 3 describes the two wayfinding aids, the method, and the apparatus used in this study. Section 4 summarizes the measured results, and section 5 discusses the findings and concludes the study.

            2. LITERATURE REVIEW

            2.1. Wayfinding and Wayfinding Aids

            Wayfinding is an activity in which a route from an origin to a destination is found and followed (Golledge, 1999). The overall goal of wayfinding is to relocate from one place to another accurately within a large-scale space (Gluck, 1990). A successful wayfinding process contains three stages (Ishikawa et al., 2008): (a) determine one's location and direction in order to orientate, (b) have an understanding of the destination and plan a route to it, and (c) execute the route. Wayfinding requires memory and attention resource so that it can be successfully and smoothly performed. If one is familiar with a wayfinding environment, then less memory and attention is needed. However, in the case of being in an unfamiliar environment and especially being under time stress, a wayfinding aid is usually helpful and necessary. The aid typically provides assistance verbally or graphically to reduce the demand of memory and attention resource and thus reduce the user's mental demand (Schmid, Richter, & Peters, 2010).

            Many wayfinding aids have been developed and can be classified into two main categories: active aids (Wu et al., 2009) and passive aids, in accordance with the way they work. Active aids encourage exploration and promote spatial knowledge construction, whereas passive aids emphasize navigation efficacy and try to reduce mental demand (skip the first two wayfinding stages and only focus on executing the route given by the aid).

            Active aids provide users with sufficient map information and help users construct a comprehensive cognitive map. The users need to complete all the three wayfinding stages with active aids. Wu et al. (2009) proposed and evaluated three active aids: human–system collaboration, animation guides, and view-in-view maps. The evaluation was based on wayfinding performances and subjective responses with tasks in a virtual environment. The results show that users benefit significantly from tools that provide more cross-scale spatial information, in terms of both wayfinding performance and the construction of spatial knowledge. The influence of individual's spatial knowledge was also observed, and it was found that view-in-view maps is the best for individuals regardless of their spatial ability, whereas the animation guides aid is good only for individuals with high spatial ability. Schmid et al. (2010) proposed a wayfinding aid, called route aware maps, to provide both local detailed map information and global overview information. Baudisch, Good, Bellotti, and Schraedley (2002) experimentally compared two wayfinding aids, focus plus context and overview plus detail (OPD), in terms of performance time, error rate, and subjective satisfaction in a virtual environment. The results show that focus plus context could significantly reduce the error rate compared to OPD. However, as discussed by the authors, the higher error rate of OPD might be due to the use of two separate screens, and accordingly the subjects need to switch their visual focus between the two screens. Moser, Degener, Wahl, and Klein (2008) introduced a novel interactive terrain visualization technique to blend geocentric and egocentric perspectives and to combine the advantages of both viewpoints while maintaining the ease of perception of a single view. Seffell, Colle, Back, and Douglass (2012) proposed two designs with Euclidean virtual three-dimensional display interfaces to enhance users' spatial knowledge acquisition. The aforementioned studies suggest that wayfinding aids with multiscale information display could potentially improve their usefulness, but caution should be taken to avoid potential side effects, such as divided attention due to separate screens. For future studies, designs with larger screen sizes are needed, and it is needed to investigate how to take the advantages of screen size and at the same time to avoid potential negative impacts.

            In situations where a navigation destination is known and a user only needs to get to the destination quickly and accurately, passive wayfinding aids (e.g., teleportation tools and GPS) are often used. These tools can graphically bring the navigator to the destination instantly and highlight the recommended route to destination. Some tools, such as logarithmic movement (Mackinlay, Card, & Robertson, 1990), let systems execute viewpoint movement once the destination is specified. Although these tools are efficient in viewpoint movement, they actually deprive the navigator of the opportunity to actively explore the environment (Wu et al., 2009) and the user has to follow the recommended route. Fenech et al. (2010) concluded that using an acoustic navigation system resulted in shorter travel time but also resulted in some negative effects, including inattention blindness, failure to detect elements in the environment, and failure to construct spatial awareness of the environment.

            2.2. GPS Interface Design

            GPS was one of the top-selling consumer technologies in 2008 (Jensen, Skovm, & Thiruravichandran, 2010). In recent years, more and more types of GPS-enabled devices were developed and successfully commercialized, including portable navigation devices (PNDs) mounted in automobiles for wayfinding, DVD-integrated GPS device for both wayfinding and in-vehicle entertainment, and cellular-phone-integrated GPS handsets for wayfinding (especially for pedestrians in developing countries as an value-adding function of cellular phones). These GSP devices were used in their corresponding scenarios. In China, PND- and DVD-integrated GPS are more often used by automobile drivers, whereas cellular phones with GPS function are less often used by drivers. Accordingly, in this study we focus on traditional GPS (PND).

            Regarding GPS interface design, researchers concern two main cognitive aspects: inattention blindness and obstacles to spatial awareness, as previously mentioned. Some studies investigated the inattention blindness effect and attempted to discover an inherent relationship between navigational performance and driving performance (Green, Hoekstra, Williams, Wen, & George, 1993; Jensen et al., 2010; Wu et al., 2008), whereas Leshed et al. (2008) indicated that GPS use may alter driving practices and may affect the spatial understanding of the driving environment. GPS makes the second wayfinding stage (having an understanding of destination and plan a route to the destination) unnecessary. Accordingly, the user is not required to have knowledge of their current location and the destination, and no explicit planning is required (Fenech et al., 2010).

            In field experiments, Ishikawa et al. (2008) compared wayfinding tasks with a mobile phone GPS, with a map, and with direct experience. The results show no benefit of travel time for GPS because the users were focusing on the continuously updating mobile phone screen with GPS. This is an indication of inattention blindness for the mobile phone GPS group. Yu, Moon, Chow, Wong, and Li (2008) proposed a new design of GPS-based human navigation aid, called CityWalker. CityWalker uses a digital fluxgate compass to rotate the map automatically according to user's orientation. CityWalker provides a low-cost solution for building a GPS-based, human-oriented navigation tool on various mobile platforms. A prototype has been implemented on the PlayStation Portable handheld console successfully. Experimental result shows that the new design is more feasible for human navigation and is more effective in terms of path-planning and more user-friendly (mainly due to map rotation and voice instructions).

            Despite the literatures on GPS interface design and evaluation, some other researchers argue that further research is needed to focus on how to present navigational information to enhance user comprehension and satisfaction (Green et al., 1993; Moldenhauer & McCrickard, 2003; Zhang, 2008). With the emergence of low-cost display and computing hardware, it becomes reasonable to consider a multiscale display of information and to promote self-exploration to address the spatial awareness problem of regular GPS.

            2.3. Multiscale Wayfinding Aids

            The term “scale” has several definitions in different situations (Lam & Quattrochi, 1992; Montello, 1993; Pereira, 2002; Reitsma & Bittner, 2003). It can be considered as a measure of the relationship between the perceived space and the human (Montello, 1993). Zhang (2008) considered scale as a parameter that coordinates a set of size-related parameters for user interactions, such as navigation speed and manipulation distance. The term “multiscale” was first introduced in Perlin and Fox (1993). The “Pad system” in this literature was a multiscale system allowing objects to be represented differently at different scales by stepwise zooming. Some other novel multiscale techniques such as zooming, OPD, and focus plus context appeared afterward (Baudisch et al., 2002; Buring, Gerken, & Reiterer, 2006; Cockburn, Karlson, & Bederson, 2008). OPD is a two-scale interface that displays both detailed information and a global context at the same time. This technique is now widely used in mapping tools (Cockburn et al., 2008). View-in-view maps mentioned earlier (Wu et al., 2009) is also a type of OPD interface and performed better than other mono-scale aids (human–system collaboration), although the overview window shows only the target representation and the navigator's current location.

            According to the aforementioned literature analysis, on one hand, GPS is widely used in today's driving and in other wayfinding tasks; on the other hand, GPS has some major limitations and could be improved with the possibility of showing multiscale information. Our attempt is to propose a hybrid GPS aid that takes advantage of both passive aid and multiscale active aid. However, to clearly investigate the strength and weakness of each kind, in this study, we choose to compare two typical wayfinding aids, namely, a simulated GPS and a DSEA. By understanding their strength and weakness, indications leading to novel hybrid GPS, which features wayfinding performance, spatial knowledge acquisition, and low mental demand, may be finally obtained.

            3. METHODS

            3.1. Wayfinding Aids to Compare

            Simulated GPS Aid

            To make a comparison with the DSEA under equal conditions, the simulated GPS aid in this study has no acoustic turn-by-turn instructions and shows only one-scale visual information: a local detailed map with a highlighted recommended route (Figure 1). The GPS works in an egocentric way (Gomez, Rousett, & Baciu, 2009; Kumagai & Allard, 2003) to better aid participants to follow the instructions, like most commercial GPS. The bolded route is the recommended route to the destination. In this study, the participants were instructed to following the recommended route. In Figure 1, A, B, C, and D were added only to indicate the elements and were not included in the simulated GPS during the experiment.

            A Comparative Study of Two Wayfinding Aids With Simulated Driving Tasks—GPS and a Dual-Scale Exploration Aid

            FIG. 1. Simulated Global Positioning System aid. A = road; B = building; C = recommended route; D = current location and orientation (color figure available online).

            Dual-Scale Exploration Aid

            Unlike a GPS aid, the DSEA serves as a dual-scale model with two windows (overview window and detail window) displaying information at two scales (Figure 2, A–F, also only for illustrative purposes; not shown in the experiment). The overview window is the square window at the bottom right of the screen. The detail window is similar to the simulated GPS but without the recommended route. With DSEA, participants have autonomy when determining the up-to-date route. The participants first determine their current location/orientation and destination from the overview window. Then, they can plan their up-to-date route to the destination by combining the knowledge obtained from the overview window and the information about available roads in the detail window.

            A Comparative Study of Two Wayfinding Aids With Simulated Driving Tasks—GPS and a Dual-Scale Exploration Aid

            All authors

            FIG. 2. Dual-scale exploration aid. A = road; B = building; C = car in detail window; D = destination; E = current location and orientation; F = corresponding area of detail window in the overview window (color figure available online).

            FIG. 2. Dual-scale exploration aid. A = road; B = building; C = car in detail window; D = destination; E = current location and orientation; F = corresponding area of detail window in the overview window (color figure available online).

            3.2. Apparatus

            An experiment was conducted on a fixed-base driving simulator (Figure 3). The simulator computer has two visual output channels: Channel 1, with a resolution of 1024 × 768, drives a projector to display virtual driving environment on a large screen in front of the simulator; Channel 2, with a resolution of 450 × 600, drives a small-size LCD screen as the wayfinding aid in this study. The size and resolution of the LCD screen was determined by analyzing the main GPS models on the market (http://zdc.zol.com.cn/211/2116679.html [in Chinese]). The LCD screen was mounted as if it were a real GPS in a car.

            A Comparative Study of Two Wayfinding Aids With Simulated Driving Tasks—GPS and a Dual-Scale Exploration Aid

            All authors
            Binfeng Li, Keming Zhu, Wei Zhang, Anna Wu & Xiaolong Zhang
            https://doi.org/10.1080/10447318.2012.702634
            Published online:
            27 January 2013

            FIG. 3. Driving simulator and the mounted LCD screen (color figure available online).

            Display full size

            FIG. 3. Driving simulator and the mounted LCD screen (color figure available online).

            3.3. The Virtual Environment

            The virtual environment, created with 3D MAX by a professional company, was a simplified (showing only roads and the surrounding buildings) model based on a medium-sized city (Foshan, Guangdong Province in South China) with a rich texture for the visual images. The roadside buildings do not correspond to the real city. Only the road network is alike. The model represents an area of 8 × 8 km with a total road length of 180 km at three levels (main road, branch road, and local road). No traffic light was included in the virtual environment. To make driving the primary task for the participants, we added some overhead signboards that displayed random numbers along the road and required the drivers to correctly report the numbers when they saw them. The report accuracy and their basic driving performance were measured in the experiment.

            3.4. Participants

            Thirty-six participants (25 male, 11 female), recruited through a local online community, took part in this experiment. The mean subject age was 27.5 years (SD = 7.9; between 20 and 53 years). The mean driving experience (indicated by the total kilometers ever driven) was 45,100 km (SD = 10,8000 km; 0–500,000 km). Novice drivers were welcome in this experiment because novice drivers tend to use GPS more often than experienced drivers. None of the participants has GPS installed in their cars, and most of them have no GPS experience at all. Accordingly we may assume no experience bias in the experiment. They were randomly assigned to one of the two groups (called GPS group and DSEA group). The spatial ability test results show that the participants' spatial ability of the GPS and DSEA groups have no significant difference (Table 2).

            3.5. Procedure and Tasks

            Upon arrival, each participant was explained about the study purpose, experimental procedure, tasks, and requirement. Then they filled out a background survey questionnaire and signed a consent form. To measure his or her spatial ability, each participant was required to complete the spatial orientation test as used in Kozhevnikov and Hegarty (2001) and Hegarty and Waller (2004). The participants were randomly assigned to either the GPS group or the DSEA group. Before starting the simulated driving task, they would have sufficient time to practice driving in the simulator with the corresponding wayfinding aids under a speed limit of 50 km/hr. An examination driving task was taken by the participants once they reported having sufficient practice. If they failed the examination, then more practice was needed until they passed before starting the following experimental task. Figure 4 shows the experimental procedure for each participant upon arrival.

            A Comparative Study of Two Wayfinding Aids With Simulated Driving Tasks—GPS and a Dual-Scale Exploration Aid

            All authors
            Binfeng Li, Keming Zhu, Wei Zhang, Anna Wu & Xiaolong Zhang
            https://doi.org/10.1080/10447318.2012.702634
            Published online:
            27 January 2013

            FIG. 4. Experimental procedure (color figure available online).

            Display full size

            FIG. 4. Experimental procedure (color figure available online).

            Each participant in either group would complete seven different wayfinding tasks at two difficulty levels, including four easy tasks and three difficult tasks, in a random order. In our study, the task difficulty (driving) was measured by the number of turns and the traveling distance, as in Wu et al. (2009). The easy task was defined as having two turns with approximately 1 km total distance, whereas the difficult task was defined as having four to six turns with approximately 2.5 km total distance.

            For each task, participants began at a starting parking area and were asked to find and reach a target parking area (destination) in the large-scale virtual city using their correspondingly assigned wayfinding aid (GPS or DSEA). During driving, the participants needed to report the number shown on every signboard (an average of five signboards per kilometer, with number and distance randomly placed) to keep the participant primarily focused on the driving task (detection, direction, and speed control). In each task, if a participant could not reach the destination within 10 min, then 10 min would be recorded as the task completion time (TCT). The number of errors (NOE; e.g., the participant turned differently from what the aids indicated [GPS group] or the participant changed back direction after a decision has already been made [DSEA]) in driving would be counted in each task. After reaching the destination, a randomly selected story was assigned to the participant to read and repeat. This process usually takes approximately 3 min to clear possible short memory effects. Then the participant needed to recall the route he or she had traveled and draw it on paper. The drawing was evaluated by route knowledge measurement (RKM). RKM was judged by comparing the route that the participant had recalled and the one that he or she had actually driven through. For each task, the total score for RKM was 100 points. An adaptive and simplified evaluation approach for judging the route recall accuracy (Ishikawa et al., 2008) was used in this analysis. Participants could take a break before starting the next task if they felt uncomfortable.

            After all seven tasks were completed, the participants were required to experience the other wayfinding aid that they had not used previously, for two easy tasks and one difficult task, to have a subjective evaluation of the two wayfinding aids. The subjective evaluation of the two aids (one tested and one just experienced) was measured by four questions for each aid (see Table 1). An adaptive satisfaction questionnaire (Cook, 1991), as was used in Wu et al. (2009), was also used in the last stage of this experimental study.

            A Comparative Study of Two Wayfinding Aids With Simulated Driving Tasks—GPS and a Dual-Scale Exploration Aid

            All authors

            https://doi.org/10.1080/10447318.2012.702634

            4. RESULTS

            The data collected are shown in Table 2, including objective indices (spatial ability, measured by degrees of deviation from the correct direction; TCT in seconds; NOE; RKM, measured by 100-point scale for memory accuracy) and subjective evaluation ratings (satisfaction, spatial awareness, ease of use, and memory requirements, all measured with 5-point rating scales; see Table 1). Normality tests were examined for the measurements before selecting parametric (two-sample T test) or nonparametric (Mann–Whitney U test) analysis. A confidence level of 95% was used for all statistical tests.

            4.1. Spatial Ability

            Table 2 indicates that the participants' spatial ability of the GPS and DSEA groups have no significant difference (GPS M = 19.3, SD = 16.7; DSEA M = 15.7, SD = 7.7; p = .937). Accordingly, subsequent comparison analysis will not consider the influence of a participant group factor in terms of SPA.

            4.2. TCT

            As Table 2 shows, the GPS group took less time to complete both the easy and the difficult tasks. For either type of task, the difference was significant between the two groups (Easy tasks: GPS M = 66.8, SD = 15.6; DSEA M = 92.4, SD = 19.2; DSEA group averagely needs 25.6 s longer TCT [relatively, 25.6/66.8 = 38.3%] to reach the destination, p < .001; Difficult tasks: GPS M = 127.1, SD = 28.8; DSEA M = 192.0, SD = 37.5; DSEA group averagely needs 64.9 s longer TCT [relatively, 64.9/127.1 = 51%], p < .001).

            4.3. NOE

            As Table 2 shows, the GPS group made fewer errors in completing both the easy and difficult tasks. For either type of task, the difference was significant (Easy tasks: GPS M = 0.4, SD = 0.6; DSEA M = 1.6, SD = 1.5; p < .001; Difficult tasks: GPS M = 0.6, SD = 0.7; DSEA M = 2.6, SD = 1.4; p = .012).

            4.4. RKM

            As Table 2 shows, the DSEA group had significantly higher RKM scores compared to the GPS group for difficult tasks (GPS M = 65.8, SD = 14.3; DSEA M = 79.3, SD = 14.8; DSEA group averagely has 13.5 points higher RKM scores than GPS group [relatively, 13.5/65.8 = 20.5%], p = .007), which indicated that the DSEA group had more accurate route information in memory. However, for easy tasks, the difference did not reach significance (GPS M = 81.4, SD = 18.8; DSEA M = 85.6, SD = 13.6; p = .467).

            4.5. Subjective Evaluation

            Participants in the DSEA group had a significantly higher satisfaction rating compared to that of the GPS group (GPS M = 3.0, SD = 1.1; DSEA M = 3.7, SD = 1.0; p = .012). In addition, participants in the DSEA group did gain a significantly higher spatial awareness rating compared to those in the GPS group (GPS M = 2.5, SD = 1.2; DSEA M = 4.1, SD = 0.7); the relative difference is (4.1 – 2.5)/2.5 = 64%, p < .001. This subjective evaluation result is qualitatively consistent with the measured RKM data. However, the GPS aid led the participants to the target area much easier than the DSEA (GPS M = 4.6, SD = 0.5; DSEA M = 3.4, SD = 0.9; p < .001), which is also qualitatively consistent with the measured TCT. Participants' ratings on the memory requirement showed a significant difference (GPS lower than DSEA) between the two wayfinding aids (GPS M = 2.4, SD = 1.0; DSEA M = 2.8, SD = 0.9; p = .032), which indicated that using GPS required more effort to memorize the route.

            5. DISCUSSIONS AND CONCLUSIONS

            5.1. Situations That Need One-Time Quick Access to a Destination

            The results show that GPS is superior to DSEA in terms of wayfinding performance in this study, with a shorter task completion time (approximately 38.1–51% less time for both the easy and difficult tasks), less turning errors, and more perceived ease of use. It may give some indications that, in situations that require quick access to a destination and that require only one-time access, using a GPS aid is more helpful. In such situations, users do not need to actively explore the space and construct a cognitive map. GPS is a type of passive wayfinding aid, which requires the users only to follow the instructions, and there is no need for the user to actually perform the first two wayfinding stages defined in Ishikawa et al. (2008).

            5.2. Situations That Need Multiple-Time Access to a Destination

            Although the results show that GPS is superior to DSEA in the study with a shorter task completion time, less turning errors, and more perceived ease of use, DSEA is superior with respect to having better route knowledge memory and higher subjective evaluation; an exception is in the ease of use (indicated in Table 2 with more satisfaction, higher perceived spatial awareness, and less memory workload in memorizing the route structure information). It may give some indications that in situations that need multiple-time access and where memorizing route structure information is important for future access, DSEA will be more helpful. In such situations, users can actively explore the appropriate space and construct a cognitive map. The users have the freedom to analyze the route strategy, plan the detailed route, and execute the wayfinding task with the help of both detailed local route information and overview route structure information. According to after-experiment interviews, participants in this experiment made the effort to find their way by themselves; as a result, they felt more interested in finding their own way in the experimental virtual city. DSEA provided detailed and contextual information simultaneously, and the participants could gain an overview impression of the environment they were driving in. The participants needed less memory to construct the cognitive map because they could glance at the overview map at any time.

            This conclusion is consistent with Autoinfo (2011), which shows that the GPS installation rate was only approximately 10%. The most significant reason for this low installation rate is that the drivers seldom drive to unfamiliar places. A further investigation shows that when driving in urban areas, drivers prefer using maps because the GPS database is not updated in time (compared to rapid road structure changes in China cities), and GPS sometimes gives wrong information, mainly because of its positioning accuracy. In such situations, DSEA will be more helpful because DSEA allows users to plan their whole route or part of their route to their destination.

            In some situations, users need quick access to a destination and need to construct a cognitive map of the route knowledge. For these situations, it can be deduced that dual-scale GPS, which provides both local guidance information (GPS) and an overview map, may be more helpful. This suggestion needs to be tested in our future experiments.

            Another indication for future GPS design is that combining DSEA and GPS to create a hybrid GPS might be more useful. The users may use DSEA for overall route planning or subdestinations planning (a series of subdestinations form an overall route to final destination), and the subdestination planning can be in a dynamic way based on updated traffic information. However, for subroute between subdestinations, the users may use a GPS way to just follow the subroute because the users may decide that no route knowledge is needed between the adjacent subdestinations. This hybrid GPS may take advantages of both DSEA and regular GPS, and result in both higher wayfinding performance, ease of use, higher route knowledge memory, and higher overall satisfaction.

            5.3. Influence of Spatial Ability

            To analyze the influence SPA on the measured variables, we divided the participants of GPS and DSEA groups each into three subgroups: the higher SPA subgroup (average rotation error lower than 10 degrees; six GPS and five DSEA participants fell in this group), the lower SPA subgroup (average rotation error over 30 degrees; six GPS and five DSEA participants fell in this group), and the intermediate subgroup (average rotation error between 10 and 30 degrees; six GPS and eight DSEA participants fell in this group). The following comparisons are between the higher and the lower subgroups of either the GPS group or the DSEA group.

            For the GPS group, the higher SPA subgroup took significantly less TCT to reach the destination (T = –3.10, p = .027) for both the easy tasks and difficult tasks (T = –2.32, p = .043). However, the two subgroups failed to reach significance in NOEs for either the easy or difficult tasks (W = 45.5, p = .248; W = 28.0, p = .059, respectively). Regarding RKM scores, the higher SPA subgroup had significantly higher RKM scores than the lower SPA subgroup for the difficult tasks (T = 2.85, p = .021), but failed to reach significance for the easy tasks (T = 1.14, p = .285). These results indicate that SPA does have some influence on wayfinding performance and route knowledge memory, especially with difficult tasks. The finding is consistent with Wu et al. (2009).

            For the DSEA group, the higher SPA subgroup took significantly less TCT to reach the destination (T = –3.10, p = .027) for the difficult tasks (T = –2.53, p = .039). However, the difference failed to reach significance for easy tasks (T = –2.05, p = .096). The two subgroups failed to reach significance in NOEs for either the easy or difficult tasks (W = 19.5, p = .100; W = 27.0, p = 1.000, respectively). Regarding RKM scores, the two subgroups failed to reach significance for either the easy tasks (T = 0.8, p = .454) or the difficult tasks (T = 1.12, p = .264). The results indicated that SPA does have influence on wayfinding performance for difficult tasks, but the influence is not significant for the wayfinding performance with the easy tasks defined in this study and for route knowledge memory. Comparing this indication with the GPS group, on one hand, we see the influence of SPA on wayfinding performance with difficult tasks; on the other hand, we also see the influence of SPA on RKM for the GPS group. However, DSEA interface design makes the influence of SPA on RKM not significant.

            5.4. Limitations

            All commercial GPSs have a limited resolution (up to 10 m) and in some situations miscalculate the user's actual position, such as on a main road versus on its neighboring side road, and accordingly give wrong instructions. This often-occurring phenomenon was not simulated in this experiment and, accordingly, might have simplified the wayfinding tasks with GPS and generated a bias. Thus, caution is required when using the tested data in this study. In the future, an on-road test will be helpful to validate the results.

            Other limitations in this study include the following: There were only 36 participants, and not enough demographic factors could be considered. The experimental study was under constrained conditions (no auditory GPS cues) in a simulated environment for just seven trials of two levels of defined tasks; accordingly, the results would only provide indications for wayfinding aid design rather than solid conclusions.

            5.5. Conclusions

            This study presented our design and evaluation for two typical wayfinding aids using simulated driving tasks in virtual environments. The results show that users can benefit from DSEA with dual-scale information in situations that require multiple-time access and that require the user to construct a cognitive map. However, in situations that need only one-time quick access to a destination, a regular one-scale GPS is superior. Both wayfinding aids have merits and disadvantages. Thus, providing both wayfinding aids and giving the choice to the users might be a good solution. Accordingly, designing a hybrid GPS that features both dual-scale map information (DSEA) and GPS might be a good direction.

            ACKNOWLEDGMENTS

            This study was supported by the National Natural Science Foundation of China under grant number 70771057 and the Program for New Century Excellent Talents in University (NCET), and Tsinghua University Research Funding (2009THZ01015).
